                     <title>William R. Trotter collection, 1980-1996.</title>
                  </titleInfo>
                  <abstract>The collection includes research materials for Trotter's book, Priest of Music: The Life of Dimitri Mitropoulos. Extensive research and interviews of noted musicians were done by Oliver Daniel who died before he could write the biography. </abstract>

                     <role>
                        <roleTerm valueURI="http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/rps">Repository</roleTerm>

            </objectXMLWrap>
resource.title: William R. Trotter collection, 1980-1996.
resource.abstract: The collection includes research materials for Trotter's book, Priest of Music: The Life of Dimitri Mitropoulos. Extensive research and interviews of noted musicians were done by Oliver Daniel who died before he could write the biography.

resource.source:
<objectXMLWrap>
               <did xmlns="urn:isbn:1-931666-22-9">
                  <repository>
                     <corpname>Mass Media and Culture</corpname>
                     <address>
                        <addressline>Special Collections, University of Maryland Libraries, Hornbake Library, College Park, MD 20742. Tel: 301-405-9212, Fax: 301-314-2709, Email: askhornbake@umd.edu</addressline>
                     </address>
                  </repository>
                  <origination>
                     <persname>Harrison, Burt</persname>
                  </origination>
                  <unittitle>Burt Harrison Papers</unittitle>
                  <unitdate>1977-1982</unitdate>
                  <unitdate>1977-1982</unitdate>
                  <physdesc>5.00 linear feet including 65 audiocassettes</physdesc>
                  <unitid>NPBA 92-9</unitid>
                  <physloc>Room 3210 (Showcase Room):70:B:Room 3210 (Showcase Room) 70 : B : </physloc>
                  <abstract>Burt Harrison spent most of his broadcasting career in the state of Washington.  He was station manager of KWSU, Washington State University at Pullman's radio station from 1959 to 1976.  During this time he served on the boards of National Association Educational Broadcasters (NAEB), National Educational Radio (NER), and the Association of Public Radio Stations.  In addition, Harrison lobbied for the inclusion of radio in the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967.  In 1977, he received the first Edward R. Murrow Award from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.  After retirement, Harrison and his wife, Dee, taped 42 oral history interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project funded by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.  The collection consists of audio cassettes, verbatim and final transcripts of interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project.  The interviewees discuss their roles and memories of public radio.</abstract>
                  <abstract>Burt Harrison spent most of his broadcasting career in the state of Washington. In addition, Harrison lobbied for the inclusion of radio in the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967.  In 1977, he received the first Edward R. Murrow Award from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.  After retirement, Harrison and his wife, Dee, taped 42 oral history interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project funded by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.  The collection consists of audio cassettes, verbatim and final transcripts of interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project.  The interviewees discuss their roles and memories of public radio.</abstract>

The interviewees discuss their roles and memories of public radio.</abstract>

The collection consists of audio cassettes, verbatim and final transcripts of interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project.  The interviewees discuss their roles and memories of public radio.</abstract>

He was station manager of KWSU, Washington State University at Pullman's radio station from 1959 to 1976.  During this time he served on the boards of National Association Educational Broadcasters (NAEB), National Educational Radio (NER), and the Association of Public Radio Stations.  In addition, Harrison lobbied for the inclusion of radio in the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967.  In 1977, he received the first Edward R. Murrow Award from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.  After retirement, Harrison and his wife, Dee, taped 42 oral history interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project funded by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.  The collection consists of audio cassettes, verbatim and final transcripts of interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project.  The interviewees discuss their roles and memories of public radio.</abstract>
               </did>

resource.title: Burt Harrison Papers 1977-1982 1977-1982
resource.abstract: Burt Harrison spent most of his broadcasting career in the state of Washington.  He was station manager of KWSU, Washington State University at Pullman's radio station from 1959 to 1976.  During this time he served on the boards of National Association Educational Broadcasters (NAEB), National Educational Radio (NER), and the Association of Public Radio Stations.  In addition, Harrison lobbied for the inclusion of radio in the Public Broadcasting Act of 1967.  In 1977, he received the first Edward R. Murrow Award from the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.  After retirement, Harrison and his wife, Dee, taped 42 oral history interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project funded by the Corporation for Public Broadcasting.  The collection consists of audio cassettes, verbatim and final transcripts of interviews for the Public Radio Oral History Project.  The interviewees discuss their roles and memories of public radio. The interviewees discuss their roles and memories of public radio.
